page.title: 01Breckland village
page.content: Oxborough is a small village on the edge of Breckland of about eighty flint and brick houses, mainly grouped round the green. Although only a few of the magnificent well grown trees of earlier days remain, some still shade the reen and the cottages that ring it. Inspite of its size Oxborough still retains its shop/postoffice, pub and picturesque part-ruined church with its terra-cotta work. To the North East the little river Gadder flos under the road to feed the moat of Oxburgh Hall,a find old house the home of the Beddingfeld family for nearly five hundred years and now in the care of the National Trust. Two farms border the village, growing sugar/beet and grain, both retaining most of their hedges in their wide fields, for this is shooting country, where pheasants and partridges abound
